data.text: In the latest issue of #FandD, we’ve assembled a lineup of accomplished authors who provide cutting-edge research, analysis, and insight into what is needed to improve health and well-being. Read the letter from the editor. https://t.co/0N9kuCZpdr https://t.co/ROeW7erC2Z

Nigeria, Africa’s largest economy, was the first country on the continent to launch a central bank digital currency. Read more about the benefits and the risks in this #IMFCountryFocus: https://t.co/kydxjFfYvu #IMFAfrica https://t.co/16hSa9HAU2

Spending and tax policies may help workers withstand the effects of automation, but policymakers should consider the long-term consequences for countries’ growth and productivity. Find out more on #IMFBlog. https://t.co/0aPjJg8q2U https://t.co/7qAq1VA6Nq

Happy New Year from the IMF!

What are you looking forward to in 2022? https://t.co/SGqYO0bKWJ

How to better help low-income countries with high debt? Improve the existing G20 Common Framework by adding clarity on timeliness and offering a debt service payment standstill, write @KGeorgieva and @CeylaP_IMF on #IMFBlog: https://t.co/ZWSOjMODOI https://t.co/SjC0eNrboR

Privately issued cryptoassets like Bitcoin come with substantial risks. Making them equivalent to a national currency is an inadvisable shortcut.

Carbon is everywhere and in almost everything but using carbon fuel harms our planet. What if we put a price on it to reduce the harm?

In the US, net wealth for the top 1% rose seven-fold more than households in the bottom 50%.
